[{"ActionResult":{"id":"9761bad4-9860-4be8-a6ef-fc6ba84489a8","result":{"SuggestPlan":{"result":{"Accepted":{"plan":"1. 1. Perform requirements and environment audit
Confirm macOS and Windows target specs, external drive mounting (`/Volumes/Mac Mini External`), reverseâ€SSH tunnel endpoints, and gather Windows username/IP. Produce a validated checklist of mandatory vs optional components before coding starts.
2. 2. Initialize unified portable repository skeleton
Create a top-level `fmla_app/` directory (no installer needed) containing:
  - `bootstrap.sh` / `bootstrap.ps1`
  - `modules/` for each functional area
  - `logs/`, `checkpoints/`, `config/`  
Git-initialize and add CI hooks for style and linting.
3. 3. Build cross-platform bootstrap launcher
Write `bootstrap.sh` (mac) and `bootstrap.ps1` (win) to:
  1. Verify dependencies (Python 3.11+, SQLite3, jq/PowerShell JSON, ssh).
  2. Export current PATHs; create virtual env in `env/`.
  3. Load last checkpoint; else start fresh.  
All subsequent modules are invoked from this launcher, capturing stdout/stderr.
4. 4. Integrate data-processing pipeline module
Port existing scripts that transform 82 GB â†’ 1.8 MB into `modules/data_pipeline/`.  
Expose idempotent CLI: `fmla data-process --resume`.  
Embed:
  - Queue manager with retry/back-off
  - Disk-space guard matching user rule
  - Ledger and hash index compatibility  
Write unit tests against 10-file fixture set.
5. 5. Implement database operations layer
Create `modules/db_layer/` wrapping the 5 SQLite DBs with `sqlite-utils`:
  - Connection pool
  - Versioned migrations
  - Full-text search helpers  
Provide Python API plus CLI commands (`fmla db search`, `fmla db migrate`).  
Add integrity check that runs at startup and on shutdown.
6. 6. Port cross-tab memory management system
Move PowerShell and bash memory scripts into `modules/memory/`.  
Refactor into a shared Python core with thin shell adapters to:
  - Append session JSON
  - Broadcast updates (`pkill -USR1` or `Send-Message`)  
Ensure atomic writes and 30-day retention. Include regression tests.
7. 7. Wrap Claude 30-thread orchestration
Encapsulate `claude_30_threads.sh` and helpers in `modules/claude_threads/`.  
Provide commands:
  - `fmla claude launch|status|restore|backup`  
Integrate with memory module so thread contexts auto-sync.
8. 8. Create plugin interface for 290+ existing tools
Under `modules/tools_bridge/` scan the tools directory at runtime, generate shims so each tool can be invoked via `fmla tool <name> [args]`.  
Log input/output, capture non-zero exits, and route failures to the new failure tracker.
9. 9. Maintain reverse SSH tunnel and cross-platform sync
Package existing tunnel scripts inside `modules/tunnel/`.  
Add watchdog that restarts tunnel if dropped.  
Implement `fmla sync --target mac|win` that rsyncs `data/`, `memory/`, and `checkpoints/` over the tunnel, respecting conflict routing rules (Needs_Review/Conflicts).
10. 10. Develop unified failure tracking & logging framework
Standardize log format (JSON lines) to `logs/<module>.log`.  
Write `modules/failure_tracker.py` that records:
  - Step name, timestamp, error, stack trace
  - Affected file or record ID  
Expose `fmla failures list|retry|export`.  
Integrate with every module via decorator or trap.
11. 11. Implement checkpointing and automated recovery
After each major step, serialize state to `checkpoints/step_<n>.json`.  
On bootstrap, detect last clean checkpoint; prompt resume or fresh start.  
Recovery routine replays pending queues and marks previously successful items to skip (idempotent).
12. 12. Establish testing matrix and continuous integration
Define pytest suites for unit and integration tests, PowerShell Pester tests for Windows.  
Matrix:
  - macOS Intel, Windows 10/11
  - Dev (sample data) vs Prod (full data, dry-run)  
CI pipeline runs in GitHub Actions with self-hosted mac and win runners via the SSH tunnel.
13. 13. Package zero-install portable bundle
Use `PyOxidizer`/`shiv` to create single-file Python executables for mac and win placed in `dist/`.  
Zip with `env/`, tools, databases, and launcher scripts.  
Optional: generate traditional installers only after field validation.
14. 14. Produce developer & user documentation
Generate Markdown docs in `docs/`:
  - Quick start
  - Module reference
  - Failure recovery playbook
  - Upgrade procedure  
Autobuild HTML via MkDocs and host through the tunnel.
15. 15. Pilot deployment, monitoring, and feedback loop
Deploy portable bundle to staging Macs and Windows PCs.  
Monitor logs via centralized viewer tunneled over SSH.  
Gather metrics (processing time, error rates), iterate, then approve production rollout."}}}},"context":[{"Directory":{"pwd":"/Users/davidquinton/dotfiles_audit","home_dir":"/Users/davidquinton","are_file_symbols_indexed":false}},{"CurrentTime":{"current_time":"2025-08-17T17:34:31.329292-07:00"}},{"ExecutionEnvironment":{"os":{"category":"MacOS"},"shell_name":"zsh","shell_version":"5.9"}}]}}]

[{"ActionResult":{"id":"39668a10-cedf-4e5b-8064-09d53365e0fe","result":{"SuggestPlan":{"result":{"Accepted":{"plan":"1. Capture and tag the next failure event
Set up a lightweight shell wrapper around Warp (e.g. bash function or small daemon) that writes a precise timestamp and a unique UUID to a log file the moment the terminal process exits unexpectedly.  
This marker becomes the reference point for all subsequent log queries.
2. Harvest system-level evidence for the marked timeframe
Within Â±5 minutes of the failure timestamp, automatically export:  
â€¢ macOS unified logs: `log show --start` / `--end` filters into a dedicated .log file  
â€¢ Crash reports and spin dumps from `~/Library/Logs/DiagnosticReports`  
â€¢ Warp-specific logs (~/Library/Application Support/Warp/logs)  
Bundle everything under a directory named with the UUID from Step 1.
3. Snapshot live process tree and network state
Immediately after detection, run and archive the output of  
`ps -axo pid,ppid,command`, `lsof -Pi -n`, and `netstat -vanp tcp`  
to capture which services (claude_api_server.py, robust_api.py, status_api.py, python, node, etc.) were alive, orphaned, or in zombie state when Warp died.
4. Collect service-level logs and stderr buffers
For each Python service (ports 8090, 8080, etc.):  
â€¢ Ensure they log to rotating files (if not, add `logging` handlers).  
â€¢ Copy the last 500 lines around the failure to the UUID bundle.  
Also capture any `.err` or `.out` files produced by supervisord/launchd.
5. Reconstruct a timeline & dependency graph
Using the harvested data, build a timestamp-ordered timeline and a dependency diagram (Warp â‡¢ shell â‡¢ bridge scripts â‡¢ Claude/GPT pipes).  
Identify the exact moment the chain breaks (e.g. pipe closed, SIGPIPE, port already in use).  
Tools: a Jupyter notebook that parses the logs and outputs a Mermaid sequence diagram.
6. Analyze recovery workflow to locate 45-minute bottlenecks
List every manual action the user currently performs to recover (reopening Warp, re-authenticating, restarting Python servers, clearing locks, etc.).  
Time each step; profile expensive operations such as environment re-initialization, large model warm-ups, or npm installs that may be triggered again.
7. Formulate and test root-cause hypotheses
Based on evidence, propose likely causes (e.g. unhandled exception in claude_api_server.pyâ€™s subprocess.run, Warp bug sending SIGHUP).  
Reproduce in a controlled session; inject faults (kill -HUP, force port collision) and observe if the same cascade occurs.  
Confirm or discard hypotheses.
8. Harden code and isolate failure domains
â€¢ Add `try/except` + exponential back-off restarts around subprocess calls in claude_api_server.py.  
â€¢ Run each bridge component under a supervisor (launchd, supervisord, or systemd-mac).  
â€¢ Use separate TTY/session for long-running services so Warp exits do not propagate SIGHUP (e.g. launch agents with `KeepAlive`).
9. Automate monitoring and early alerts
Implement a health-check endpoint aggregator (curl /health on all services every 30 s).  
If any fail 3Ã— consecutively, send a macOS notification and Slack/Webhook.  
Log metrics (uptime, restart counts) to a local Prometheus + Grafana Lite or plain CSV.
10. Build one-shot auto-recovery script
Create `recover_ai_bridge.sh` that:  
1. Kills orphaned processes occupying ports 8080/8090.  
2. Clears temporary sockets/lockfiles.  
3. Relaunches the supervisor which in turn restarts all services.  
Wire this script into the monitoring alert so it can be triggered automatically or with a single click.
11. Document SOP and schedule regular failure drills
Write a concise runbook (README.md) covering detection, logs, manual override, and the recovery script.  
Put a recurring calendar invite (e.g. monthly) to simulate a failure, run the drills, and ensure recovery time stays under 2 minutes."}}}},"context":[{"Directory":{"pwd":"/Users/davidquinton/dotfiles_audit","home_dir":"/Users/davidquinton","are_file_symbols_indexed":false}},{"CurrentTime":{"current_time":"2025-08-17T17:02:07.714434-07:00"}},{"ExecutionEnvironment":{"os":{"category":"MacOS"},"shell_name":"zsh","shell_version":"5.9"}}]}}]

# ROOT CAUSE ANALYSIS: .zshrc Corruption Pattern

## EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
**15 scripts** with **no coordination** repeatedly appending to ~/.zshrc causing:
- File bloat from 383 bytes â†’ 59,964 bytes (156x growth)
- Multiple conflicting function definitions
- Performance degradation and shell instability

## PRIMARY ROOT CAUSES IDENTIFIED

### 1. **DUPLICATE FUNCTION DEFINITIONS** (Critical)
**Location:** Lines 1804, 1810, 1835, 1862, 1871 in .zshrc.backup.20250817_121937
**Impact:** Multiple preexec() and precmd() definitions cause:
- Function conflicts and race conditions
- Infinite execution loops
- Shell hook system breakdown

### 2. **NON-IDEMPOTENT INSTALLERS** (Critical) 
**Offending scripts with NO idempotency checks:**
- quick_ollama_fix.sh (lines 46-47)
- drive_mapper.sh (lines 200-201)
- install_paste_sanitizer.sh (lines 22, 55)
- live_session_logger.sh (line 140)
- warp_memory_service.sh (line 107)
- night_mode.sh (line 11)
- automation_control.sh (line 204)
- universal_ai_memory_loader.sh (line 274)
- ultimate_invisible_ai_system.sh (line 193)

**Result:** Content gets appended repeatedly on every execution.

### 3. **NO ATOMIC WRITE PROTECTION**
**Issue:** Raw `>> ~/.zshrc` operations with no file locking
**Impact:** Concurrent writes can corrupt file during multi-script execution

### 4. **MASSIVE CONTENT DUPLICATION**
**Pattern found:** Same aliases, exports, and functions repeated 10+ times
**Example:** OLLAMA_MODELS export appears in multiple scripts
**Size impact:** Single configs becoming 50KB+ files

## TIMELINE CORRELATION
- **Aug 17 08:11:** First major bloat event (55KB)
- **Aug 17 12:19:** Peak bloat event (58KB) 
- **Aug 17 15:59:** Manual cleanup attempt (2.9KB)
- **Pattern:** Each automation run adds ~5-10KB of duplicate content

## BLAST RADIUS
- **Shell startup time:** Degraded from instant to 2-3 seconds
- **New tab creation:** Frequent failures and hangs
- **Memory usage:** High due to duplicate function loading
- **Maintenance overhead:** Manual cleanups required multiple times daily

## RECOMMENDED IMMEDIATE ACTIONS
1. Implement atomic write helpers (safe_zshrc_update.sh)
2. Modularize configuration (~/.zshrc.d approach)
3. Add mandatory idempotency checks to all installers
4. Deploy continuous syntax validation with auto-rollback

[{"ActionResult":{"id":"5e7430ab-3e6c-456e-8dea-fa6982b8d434","result":{"SuggestPlan":{"result":{"Accepted":{"plan":"1. Inventory & Baseline Current .zshrc State
1. Gather every backup copy of ~/.zshrc* (e.g. .zshrc.backup.*) and place them in ~/dotfiles_audit/.  
2. Compute checksums and build a timeline table (mtime, size, checksum) to see when corruption events occurred.  
3. Run `zsh -n` on each version; record which ones fail syntax-check and the exact error lines.  
Deliverable: `baseline_report.md` summarising good vs. bad snapshots.
2. Catalogue All Writers That Touch .zshrc
1. Grep the entire external drive and $HOME for patterns that append/modify the file:  
   `rg -l '(>>|>|sed .* -i).*\.zshrc' /Volumes/Mac\ Mini\ External "$HOME"`  
2. From context we already know at least:  
   â€¢ tools/install_fmla_functions.sh  
   â€¢ tools/warp_autofix_unified.sh (install_to_zshrc)  
3. List every script, the command used (append, sed, etc.), and whether it runs interactively or in background.  
Deliverable: `writers_matrix.csv` mapping script â†’ line numbers â†’ modification style.
3. Root-Cause Analysis of Corruption Patterns
Inspect the broken snapshots to detect signatures:  
â€¢ Truncated files â‡’ concurrent writes or abrupt power-loss.  
â€¢ Duplicate or half-written blocks â‡’ repeated >> appends without idempotency check.  
â€¢ Unbalanced quotes/brackets â‡’ echo without proper escaping.  
Correlate corruption timestamps with writers_matrix to pinpoint the culprit script(s).  
Deliverable: `rca_findings.md` with direct links to offending code lines.
4. Implement Atomic & Idempotent Write Helpers
Create unified helper `safe_zshrc_update.sh` that every installer sources:  
```bash
safe_append () {
  local block_id="$1" tmp="$(mktemp)"
  grep -q "$block_id" ~/.zshrc && return 0
  { printf "\n# >>> %s >>>\n" "$block_id"; cat; printf "# <<< %s <<<\n" "$block_id"; } > "$tmp"
  ( flock 9 && cat "$tmp" >> ~/.zshrc ) 9>~/.zshrc.lock
}
```  
â€¢ Uses flock-based lock file to prevent concurrent writes.  
â€¢ Writes to temp file then appends atomically.  
Refactor install_fmla_functions.sh and warp_autofix_unified.sh to use this helper instead of raw `>>`.
5. Modularise Configuration (~/.zshrc.d)
1. Create ~/.zshrc.d/ with sub-files: warp_autofix.zsh, fmla_functions.zsh, etc.  
2. Replace current huge ~/.zshrc with:  
```zsh
for f in ~/.zshrc.d/*.zsh(.N); do source "$f"; done
```  
3. Update each installer script to **write only its own file**, never the root .zshrc.  
Benefit: corruption of one module cannot nuke the whole config.
6. Continuous Syntax Validation & Auto-Rollback
Add a post-write hook inside `safe_zshrc_update.sh`:  
```bash
if ! zsh -n ~/.zshrc; then
  mv ~/.zshrc.bad.$(date +%s)
  cp ~/.zshrc.bak "$HOME/.zshrc"
  terminal-notifier -message "ðŸš¨ .zshrc syntax error â€“ rolled back"
fi
```  
Keeps last-known-good copy and instantly reverts on failure.
7. Version-Control Dotfiles With Git
1. Initialise `~/dotfiles` repo; move .zshrc and .zshrc.d there, symlink back.  
2. Add pre-commit hook that runs `zsh -n` on all .zsh files.  
3. Nightly cron job pushes to remote/private repo for extra safety.
8. Update Developer Guidelines & Script Templates
Publish `dotfiles_contribution_guidelines.md` describing:  
â€¢ Always use safe_zshrc_update.sh.  
â€¢ One feature â†’ one file in ~/.zshrc.d.  
â€¢ Mandatory `zsh -n` + shellcheck before commit.  
Provide template installer script that follows the rules.
9. Deploy Monitoring & Alerting
1. Wrap Warp new-tab monitor to call `zsh -n ~/.zshrc` on every tab open; if fails, show big red banner and block session.  
2. Log every successful or failed modification in `/var/log/zshrc_changes.log` with timestamp, PID, and calling script.  
3. Optional: push notifications via macOS or Slack webhook.
10. Clean-Up & Legacy Block Deactivation
1. Remove any direct `>> ~/.zshrc` calls from legacy scripts that are now redundant.  
2. Add safeguard alias in ~/.zshrc:  
```zsh
alias append_to_zshrc='echo "âŒ Use safe_zshrc_update.sh!" 1>&2'
```
